The original owner of this historic building is Raja Rajendra Shitol Raja, a descendant of the Sisodia dynasty. These clans came from the north and became local about twelve hundred years ago, and for many centuries they had uninterrupted national rights. He was the rewarder of about 350 villages like Pashan, Lavale, Hadapsar, Wanwadi, Manjari, Moshi in Pune area. Even today, in the 21st century, the records of Shitole Deshmukh as the owner of land are drawn from those villages.
The land used to built Shaniwarwada in Pune was the agricultural land of Sardar Shitole Deshmukh. The land was given to the Peshwas by the Shitole government for the construction of Shaniwarwada, in return for which they were granted bail at Baner and Javalarjun.

Later, Sardar Shitole's Jahagiri extended to Hoshangabad, Shahazabad, Khandwa, Sonpat, Panipat, Narwar, Ujjain, Gwalior etc. districts of Madhya Pradesh and to Khandesh along with Satara, Pune, Ahmednagar, Nashik districts of Maharashtra.
A person from this family had a vision of Narasimha in this Vastu. Hence God Narasimha is the deity of this family
Ganpati Mandir, 73/A, Ramganesh Gadkari Path, Near Shree Kasba, Yashodatta Housing Society, Kasba Peth, Pune, Maharashtra 411011
